📦 Types of Prepositions

In German, prepositions affect the case of the noun that follows them. There are three types:

  • Dativ Prepositions – make the sentence case Dativ
  • Akkusativ Prepositions – make the sentence case Akkusativ
  • Wechselpräpositionen – can be either Dativ or Akkusativ depending on the sentence

🖼️ Here's a table of common prepositions:

🧠 Examples – Dativ and Akkusativ Preps

  • We come without our car – "ohne" is Akkusativ → wir kommen ohne unser auto
  • He plays with his ball – "mit" is Dativ → er spielt mit seinem ball
  • You (formal) can cook for your father – "für" is Akkusativ → sie können für ihren vater kochen
  • I will come after my mother – "nach" is Dativ + modal verb structure → ich werde nach meiner mutter kommen

⏱️ Note: Because of nach, the word "mother" becomes Dativ.
Because of werde (modal verb), the main verb kommen moves to the end in infinitive form.

⚖️ Wechsel Prepositions – Both Dativ & Akkusativ

Wechselpräpositionen can act as either Dativ or Akkusativ depending on the situation:

  • Dativ: if there is no movement/change of place
  • Akkusativ: if there is movement/change of place

💡 In A1 and A2 level, we treat Wechselprepositionen as Dativ unless very clear movement is involved.

🔁 Wechsel – Examples

  • I go into my house (movement → Akkusativ)
    ich gehe in mein haus
  • I live in my house (no movement → Dativ)
    ich wohne in meinem haus
  • I put the bag on the table (movement → Akkusativ)
    ich stelle die tasche auf den tisch
  • The bag lies on the table (static → Dativ)
    die tasche liegt auf dem tisch

📘 Shortened Forms in German

Like English contracts "is not" → "isn't", German also shortens certain common combinations.

  • zu + dem → zum
    ich gehe zu dem büro → ich gehe zum büro
  • zu + der → zur
    ich gehe zu der schule → ich gehe zur schule

🧘‍♂️ Don't worry! You can always use the full form.

✅ Summary

  • Prepositions can affect the case (Dativ/Akkusativ)
  • Wechselpräpositionen switch between the two based on movement
  • Use Dativ for mit, nach, zu, aus, bei, seit, von
  • Use Akkusativ for für, ohne, bis, durch, gegen, um
  • Wechsel include: in, auf, an, hinter, neben, über, unter, vor, zwischen

✔ Keep practicing with simple examples!
